labels.name: authentication
labels.description: Issues with the Authentication platform

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Following https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/254810 let's do this for the dynamic auth provider stuff too. > @TylerLeonhardt @bamurtaugh there is an interesting negative side effect of this work that might annoy users: because we open VS Code from a local host page, this dialog seems to not remember the choice to never ask again: > > > > At least in Chrome, I always get the dialog. Probably because Chrome cannot guarantee what page is running. > > I have a feeling to fix this we would actually need to redirect to some vscode.dev presence that then calls back into VS Code somehow. _Originally posted by @bpasero in [#250086](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/250086#issuecomment-3051128254)_ We should be able to just add: `https://vscode.dev/redirect?uri=THELOCALHOSTURIGOESHERE` to that and it'll work Basically apply this PR: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/254841 to the MCP auth, dynamic auth stuff.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No - related to VS Code API for extensions that create Test Runs

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
Version: 1.103.0-insider (Universal)
Commit: 8c0b3c16f47d628d0d767358d5a3fa1d95237f70
Date: 2025-07-31T18:43:19.777Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Darwin arm64 24.5.0

We programmatically use the VS Code API to `createTestRun` and we create Test Runs without a TestRunProfile. As per the docs:

> extensions may programmatically create requests not associated with any profile

Our extension also sets file coverage for the test run with the `addCoverage` method.

In the `editor/title`, we see the `testing.toggleInlineCoverage` action appear when it does nothing. The VS Code API to provide the coverage for this action is surfaced via the `TestRunProfile`, which is undefined in our case.

Unless I'm missing something, it seems that the action should be hidden in our case, and this is a bug?

title: Bug Report: Faulty Looping Behavior in GitHub Copilot
body:
Summary:
When attempting to edit a file (src\XodusExporter.java), GitHub Copilot entered an infinite loop, repeatedly listing the file 470 times with "0 lines changed" and failing to complete the prompt. This behavior persisted until manual interruption, leaving the prompt in a hung state.

Steps to Reproduce:

Open a file in Visual Studio Code (e.g., src\XodusExporter.java).
Trigger an edit operation via GitHub Copilot.
Cancel the operation before it completes.
Observe the agent entering a loop, repeatedly listing the file with no changes.
Expected Behavior:
The agent should gracefully handle the cancellation, stop the operation, and return control to the user without entering a loop.

Actual Behavior:

The agent entered a loop, listing the same file (src\XodusExporter.java) 470 times with "0 lines changed."
The prompt became unresponsive, consuming resources and failing to complete the request.
After manual interruption, the agent failed to generate a valid response, displaying the error: "Response contained no choices."
Environment:

OS: Windows
Editor: Visual Studio Code
GitHub Copilot Version: 1.102.3
File: src\XodusExporter.java
Additional Context:

The issue appears to stem from a bug in the agent's state management when handling cancellations.
The looping behavior suggests the agent was retrying the same operation unnecessarily.
The subsequent error ("Response contained no choices") indicates a failure in recovery after the looping was interrupted.
Suggested Fix:

Implement proper cancellation handling to ensure the agent stops operations immediately upon user request.
Add safeguards to prevent retry loops when no changes are detected.
Improve error recovery mechanisms to handle interruptions gracefully.


*above was created by `github-copilot-chat` over `GPT-4o`

title: Compare active file with clipboard editor order

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: diff-editor
labels.description: Diff editor issues

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body: When you run the command `File: Compare Active File with Clipboard` the clipboard is in the left pane of the diff editor, making it more like the reverse `File: Compare Clipboard with Active File` in my opinion. The solution would be to plainly change the order and either add another function that does the reverse (currently implemented) order, or add a settings entry where you choose the default behavior. A secondary request would also be to make sure the swap sides button is available for this function (it's not present for clipboard comparison), but that seems to be because of the hacky way the `clipboardCompare{int}` scheme is implemented, and thus I think that could be considered a bug rather than a feature request. I find myself using this function a lot these days when getting code written by external tools such as Gemini Canvas, and want to quickly see what the actual changes are for each iteration. I've seen this request brought up elsewhere before, with the solution being offered is using the swapdiff extension by shalimski, but that is still a bit buggy (opens a new editor when swapping) and requires an extra step. I haven't contributed here before so I'm not aware how things work around here, but I could take this upon myself if needed and just implement the first solution, which would be good enough for my current requirements. I don't know how fast things move around here though, some quick insight would be appreciated. Relevant code: [fileActions.ts#L848](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/ec0f0be4a71892d46a136811f5a5c160f032f129/src/vs/workbench/contrib/files/browser/fileActions.ts#L827) ```Version: 1.102.2 (user setup) Commit: c306e94f98122556ca081f527b466015e1bc37b0 Date: 2025-07-22T12:15:48.520Z Electron: 35.6.0 ElectronBuildId: 11847422 Chromium: 134.0.6998.205 Node.js: 22.15.1 V8: 13.4.114.21-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

title: "The window is not responding" warning over and over, despite VSCode working fine. Fresh install.
body: - VS Code Version: 1.102.3 - OS Version: Windows 11 Version10.0.26100 Build 26100 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open VSCode 2. Open any folder 3. wait ~10-15 seconds 4. This window pops up saying the window is not responding 5. Close the warning, repeat from step 3 I can use VSCode fine, but whenever I close this warning it pops back up within a couple of seconds. The window is responding fine. I just installed VSCode on this machine.

This is UNACCEPTABLE [ User] Show me some some Kaldi forum posts and github issues which show this [assistant] Summarized conversation history Here are some direct references from Kaldi forums and GitHub issues that discuss the requirement for disambiguation symbols in phones.txt for context-dependent models and ComposeContext: 1. Kaldi GitHub Issue: "phones.txt does not contain disambiguation symbol" https://github.com/kaldi-asr/kaldi/issues/4042 User reports: "phones.txt does not contain disambiguation symbol #0, which is required for ComposeContext." Response: "You need to add a disambiguation symbol (e.g., #0) to phones.txt for context-dependent models. This is required by ComposeContext and other FST operations." 2. Kaldi Help Forum: "Disambiguation symbols in phones.txt" http://kaldi-asr.org/forums.html (search for "disambiguation symbol phones.txt") Example thread: "Why do I need #0 in phones.txt for GMM alignment?" Answer: "Disambiguation symbols are required for context-dependent decoding graphs. If you use ComposeContext, you must have at least one disambiguation symbol in phones.txt." 3. Montreal Forced Aligner GitHub Issue: "No disambiguation symbol in phones.txt" https://github.com/MontrealCorpusTools/Montreal-Forced-Aligner/issues/537 User: "Alignment fails, ComposeContext returns empty ilabels_out, no #0 in phones.txt." Maintainer: "You need to add a disambiguation symbol (e.g., #0) to phones.txt. This is a Kaldi requirement for context-dependent models." 4. This is used by ComposeContext and other FST operations." These references show that the requirement for a disambiguation symbol in phones.txt is a well-known issue in the Kaldi and MFA communities, especially when using context-dependent models and ComposeContext. The common workaround is to manually add a symbol like #0 to phones.txt if it is missing. [User] 1. title: VS Code Jupyter cell content turns invisible after GitHub Copilot edit

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **No** - VS Code Version: `1.102.3 (user setup)` - Commit: `488a1f239235055e34e673291fb8d8c810886f81` - OS Version: `Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100` - Electron: `35.6.0` - Node.js: `22.15.1` - Python: `3.12.4` - GitHub Copilot Extension Version: `1.350.0` - Jupyter Extension Version: `2025.6.0` - Theme: `Dark` --- ### Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a `.ipynb` notebook in VS Code. 2. Trigger GitHub Copilot to suggest/edit code in a cell. 3. Accept the Copilot suggestion or let it edit the cell. 4. Observe the cell becomes unreadable — content is present but invisible. --- ### Expected Behavior: The code should remain fully visible and editable after Copilot suggests or edits content inside a Jupyter cell. --- ### Actual Behavior: - The cell background turns dark/black and text is no longer visible. - The code still exists in the cell (it runs), but cannot be seen or edited easily. - Reloading or changing the theme temporarily fixes it. --- ### Additional Context: This issue seems to be triggered specifically by **Copilot's edits** to Jupyter notebook cells. It does **not occur with regular typing or auto-complete**. --- ### Temporary Workarounds: - Reloading the notebook or VS Code. - Switching themes (e.g., from dark to light and back). --- ### Screenshot: ---

title: Don't refresh cached globals automatically
body: It turns out that on Windows the `exec` calls can end up blocking the exthost for over a second: This is likely due to Windows Defender, but adding node to exclusions didn't seem to help. Because of this, plus we shouldn't be launching processes so often, the caching now must be explicitly cleared in order to get the latest. This is just a limitation we'll have to include in the documentation (https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-docs/issues/8700). Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259343 Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/256746 Merge first: - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/259347 - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/259350 Before (after reload, ext host initialized): ![Recording 2025-08-03 at 05 18 39](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ad79c813-02da-4fae-b205-393e6ea0f5b9) After (after reload, ext host initialized): ![Recording 2025-08-03 at 05 17 23 (1)](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9769f1c7-0c0a-4678-b8d3-a026bb1d2589)

title: quick suggestions are indented on accept within switch statements with curly braces
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->

<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.102.3
- OS Version:
NAME="Pop!_OS"
VERSION="22.04 LTS"


Steps to Reproduce:

When coding C# if I start with:

```
switch (command)
{
	case "cd":
	{
		var word = "test";
		break;
	}
}
```

and then highlight var and accept the quick suggestion to either fix formatting or replace var with an explicit type, then I end up with

```
switch (command)
{
	case "cd":
	{
			string word = "test";
		break;
	}
}
```

this behaviour is independent of the auto indent setting.

however, if we dont use the curly braces and use

```
switch (command)
{
	case "cd":
		var word = "test";
		break;
}
```
then the quick suggestions format things correctly. Its as if vscode is counting both the case: and { and indenting things twice (which then means the indentation is not preserved)

Using curly braces within switch cases is valid syntax and has valid uses, so it would be nice if this was fixed.

title: Critical Data Loss Bug in Encoding Handling: Ctrl+Z Causes Permanent Content Corruption

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

labels.name: file-encoding
labels.description: File encoding type issues

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No **Environment**: - VS Code Version: 1.102.3 - OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 - Reproducible: Always - ***Note**: This English description is translated by DeepSeek from Chinese. It may not fully or accurately convey the original meaning. For exact details, please refer to the Chinese reproduction steps at the end.* **Bug Description**: When switching file encodings and using undo (Ctrl+Z), VS Code enters a state that leads to permanent loss of original file content. Critical failures occur in: 1. Missing "save changes?" prompt when closing unsaved files 2. Failure to preserve manually selected encoding (GBK) after restart 3. Irreversible corruption of original file content after specific undo operations **Steps to Reproduce**: 1. Create a text file in Notepad with ANSI encoding (GBK) containing Chinese (e.g., "这是一段ANSI编码的文本") 2. Open in VS Code (defaults to UTF-8, shows garbled text) 3. Click encoding status (UTF-8) → "Reopen with Encoding" → Select GBK → Chinese displays correctly 4. Press Ctrl+Z → Encoding remains GBK but content reverts to UTF-8 garbled text → File enters unsaved state 5. Close VS Code via window's close button (X) → **BUG: No save prompt appears** 6. Reopen VS Code and the file → **BUG: Encoding resets to UTF-8, file still unsaved** 7. Repeat step 3 → **CRITICAL BUG: File shows as saved but original content is permanently corrupted** **Expected Behavior**: 1. Always prompt to save when closing unsaved files 2. Persist manually selected encoding after restart 3. Preserve original file content across undo operations 4. Never automatically change saved state without user confirmation **Impact**: - Permanent unrecoverable loss of original file content - Broken workflow for non-UTF8 encoded files - Undo operation corrupts critical editor state **复现步骤**： 1. 用Windows记事本创建ANSI编码文本文件并写入中文内容（如："这是一段ANSI编码的文本"） 2. 用VS Code打开该文件（默认为UTF-8编码 文本内容显示乱码） 3. 点击右下角UTF-8 → "通过编码重新打开" → 选择GBK → 文件内的中文正常显示 4. 按下Ctrl Z → 编码仍显示GBK但内容变回乱码 → 同时文件变为未保存状态 5. 点击VS Code程序窗口关闭按钮(X) → **关键问题：无保存提示** 6. 重新打开VS Code和文件 → **关键问题：编码从之前的GBK变为UTF-8，但文件仍为未保存状态** 7. 重复步骤3 → **关键问题：文件变为已保存状态但原始内容已经消失并未还原**

title: Add Optional Sandbox Execution for `run_in_terminal` on macOS and Linux
body:
I propose adding an option to execute commands launched via the `run_in_terminal` tool within a sandboxed environment on both macOS and Linux.

On macOS, this could be implemented using `sandbox-exec`, following the examples of tools like OpenAI’s `codex-cli` and Google’s `gemini-cli`, both of which use `sandbox-exec` to isolate command execution:

* [https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli/tree/packages/cli/src/utils](https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli/tree/820169ba2e0777ee2bee240f063649cc4b2b107f/packages/cli/src/utils)
* [https://github.com/openai/codex/tree/codex-cli/src/utils/agent/sandbox](https://github.com/openai/codex/tree/81bb1c9e264095708a01f6326bf8d527a6b2d47b/codex-cli/src/utils/agent/sandbox)

On Linux, similar sandboxing can be achieved using existing mechanisms such as Landlock:

* [https://github.com/openai/codex/blob/main/README.md#platform-sandboxing-details](https://github.com/openai/codex/blob/main/README.md#platform-sandboxing-details)
* [https://landlock.io/](https://landlock.io/)

Providing this capability natively in VS Code would improve the security of terminal-based command execution, especially in LLM-assisted workflows.

title: MCP Sampling: `includeContext` Support
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
It looks the current implementation of MCP sampling does not support the [context inclusion/`includeContext`](https://modelcontextprotocol.info/docs/concepts/sampling/#context-inclusion) feature of the MCP sampling spec.

Without this, there doesn't seem to be any way to include the current chat context (i.e., the parts of the conversation leading up to the sampling request) in the request itself.

Thank you for considering this feature request. I believe it will greatly enhance the usability and flexibility of the MCP sampling implementation in VSCode.

title: Remove strikethrough formatting from True Inline View in Diff Editor

labels.name: diff-editor
labels.description: Diff editor issues

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.102.3 - OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.5.0 **Description:** The strikethrough formatting of deletions in the Diff Editor with True Inline View is hard to read. Obstructing text with horizontal lines interferes with the shape recognition of your eyes and makes the text below it hard to read, especially when the text contains horizontal lines too like `-`, `=` or `_`. ~~You can easily conclude how reading shapes like 1 + 1 = 2 with strikethrough is bad~~ and how much easier it is to read 1 + 1 = 2 without. Even more, for a single deleted character that contains horizontal lines like `-`, `=` or `_` it's hard to even identify it, since the horizontal line directly interferes with it. Background color is much better to represent additions and deletions of text, which diff editors already use. It's unnecessary to add a second representations for deletions with strikethrough formatting. **Steps to Reproduce:** 1. Enable `diffEditor.experimental.useTrueInlineView` in Settings. 2. Read diffs. **Actual Result:** **Expected Result:**

title: Enable JSON file-based policy management on Linux by default
body:
This PR enables JSON file-based policy management on Linux systems by default, eliminating the need for the `__enable-file-policy` command-line argument.

## Background

Previously, VS Code on Linux required the `__enable-file-policy` flag to enable JSON-based policy management, while Windows and macOS used their respective native policy systems (Windows Registry and macOS Bundle Identifier). This inconsistency meant Linux users had to explicitly enable policy support through command-line arguments, making deployment and administration more complex.

## Changes

### Core Implementation

Modified `src/vs/platform/environment/common/environmentService.ts` to provide a policy file path on Linux systems by default:

```typescript
// Enable JSON file-based policy management on Linux by default
if (isLinux) {
    const vscodePortable = env['VSCODE_PORTABLE'];
    if (vscodePortable) {
        return URI.file(join(vscodePortable, 'policy.json'));
    }
    return joinPath(this.userHome, this.productService.dataFolderName, 'policy.json');
}
```

### Policy File Location

- **Standard installation**: `~/.vscode-oss/policy.json`
- **Portable installation**: `$VSCODE_PORTABLE/policy.json`

### Platform Behavior

| Platform | Default Policy Service | Policy Source |
|----------|------------------------|---------------|
| **Linux** | FilePolicyService | `~/.vscode-oss/policy.json` |
| Windows | NativePolicyService | Windows Registry |
| macOS | NativePolicyService | Bundle Identifier |

## Testing

Added comprehensive test suite in `src/vs/platform/environment/test/common/linuxPolicyFile.test.ts` that verifies:

- Policy file path generation on Linux with and without flags
- Portable mode support (`VSCODE_PORTABLE` environment variable)
- Backward compatibility on non-Linux platforms
- Integration with existing policy service selection logic

## Backward Compatibility

- **Linux**: Now provides JSON policy support by default (new feature)
- **Windows/macOS**: Behavior unchanged - still uses native policy systems by default
- **All platforms**: The `__enable-file-policy` flag continues to work as before

## Benefits

1. **Simplified deployment**: Linux administrators no longer need command-line arguments for policy management
2. **Consistent experience**: All platforms now have default policy support
3. **Standard conventions**: Uses existing VS Code configuration directory structure
4. **Zero breaking changes**: Existing deployments continue to work without modification

This change leverages the existing `FilePolicyService` infrastructure and integrates seamlessly with the current policy service selection logic in both main and CLI processes.

> [!WARNING]
>
> <details>
> <summary>Firewall rules blocked me from connecting to one or more addresses</summary>
>
> #### I tried to connect to the following addresses, but was blocked by firewall rules:
>
> - `electronjs.org`
>   - Triggering command: `node-gyp` (dns block)
>
> If you need me to access, download, or install something from one of these locations, you can either:
>
> - Configure [Actions setup steps](https://gh.io/copilot/actions-setup-steps) to set up my environment, which run before the firewall is enabled
> - Add the appropriate URLs or hosts to the custom allowlist in this repository's [Copilot coding agent settings](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/settings/copilot/coding_agent) (admins only)
>

title: [WIP] JSON File-Based Policy Management Support on Linux
body:
Coding agent has begun work on **JSON File-Based Policy Management Support on Linux** and will replace this description as work progresses.

<details><summary>See problem context</summary>

TITLE: JSON File-Based Policy Management Support on Linux

USER INTENT: The user aims to implement JSON file-based policy management for Linux in a way that supports both system-wide and user-specific policy files.

TASK DESCRIPTION: The user wants to modify the existing policy management system in VS Code to allow for multiple policy file locations on Linux, enabling both enterprise-level management and individual user configurations.

EXISTING: The current implementation only supports a user-specific policy file located at `~/.vscode/policy.json`. The user has identified the need for additional system-wide policy file locations.

PENDING: The user needs to implement changes in the following files to support the new policy management structure:
- **`src/vs/code/electron-main/main.ts`**
- **`src/vs/code/node/cliProcessMain.ts`**
- **`src/vs/platform/environment/common/environmentService.ts`**

CODE STATE: The user is looking to replace the existing `FilePolicyService` with a new service that can handle multiple policy files. The proposed solutions include:
- A `MultiplexPolicyService` that combines multiple `FilePolicyService` instances.
- A new `LinuxPolicyService` that inherits from `AbstractPolicyService`.

RELEVANT CODE/DOCUMENTATION SNIPPETS:
- Current user-specific policy file path: `~/.vscode/policy.json`
- Proposed system-wide policy file paths:
  - `/etc/vscode/policies.json`
  - `/usr/share/vscode/policies.json`
- Proposed user-specific policy file path: `~/.config/vscode/policies.json`
- Environment variable override path.

OTHER NOTES: The user has reiterated the request for JSON file-based policy management multiple times, indicating a strong focus on this feature. The assistant's previous responses were canceled, suggesting a need for clearer and more actionable guidance.

</details>
